title: Data
text: two data-sets embedded meatrics: expert_graders devices. datasets emulate expected format input data-frame(s) functions. Traits follow naming conventions sample datasets functions may rely recognize appropriate trait. functions rely pivoting data-frame wide format, using to_wide() . data-processing functions include merge_device_grader() outputs merged data-frame wide format merge_device_grader_long() outputs merged data-frame long format.

#   ²​meat_colour, ³​ribfat_cold, ⁴​aus_marbling, ⁵​msa_marbling ## # ℹ Use `print(n = ...)` to see more rows # load device data data("devices") devices ## # A tibble: 5,544 × 10 ## # Groups:   kill_date, body_no [608] ##    kill_date  body_no cold_grader fat_co…¹ meat_…² ribfa…³ aus_m…⁴ msa_m…⁵   ema ##    <date>     <chr>   <fct>       <fct>    <fct>     <dbl> <fct>     <dbl> <dbl> ##  1 2021-12-06 192     C1          0        4            NA 1           360    74 ## title: Technical
text: Note: assumption Fleiss Kappa may violated particular case-study. Fleiss et al. (2003) states: “raters responsible rating one subject assumed responsible rating another”. dataset satisfy assumption raters randomly-selected larger population raters. Fleiss Kappa extension Cohen’s Kappa, assesses inter-rater reliability three raters categorical variables factoring agreement due chance. \[ \kappa = \frac{\bar{P}-\bar{P}_e}{1-\bar{P}_e} \] \(\bar{P}\) defined observed agreement, \(\bar{P}_e\) expected agreement ratings completely random. Hence, numerator defined degree agreement actually achieved chance whereas denominator degree agreement attainable chance. fleiss_meat() reports category-wise Fleiss Kappa, can interpreted probability randomly chosen rater assigning item category, given another randomly chosen rater also assigned item category. formula \(A_{k}\) , agreement category \(k\) : \[ A_{k} = \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n}r_{ik}(r_{ik}-1)}{\sum_{=1}^{n}r_{ik}(r_{}-1)} \] \(r_{ik}\) number graders assigned item \(\) category \(k\) , \(r_{}\) total number ratings total \(n\) number items (assuming item rated 2 graders). context dataset, expert_graders, item \(\) body_no kill_date combination \(k\) available levels categorical/discrete trait.  function extended allow comparisons device category-wise agreement expert grader category–wise agreement.
code: fleiss(expert_graders, device_status = FALSE, variable = "meat_colour") fleiss(expert_graders, df2 = devices, device_status = FALSE, variable = "meat_colour")

title: Technical
text: ICC commonly used describe strongly units group resemble one another. sense, can also seen assessment rater agreement. summarise, ICC can considered ratio looking variance interest divided total variance. derived 10 different types ICC 6 defined Shrout Fleiss (1979). relevant consider two-way mixed average score ICC (ICC3k) two-way mixed single-rater score (ICC3) purpose R package. two-way mixed model defines \(k\) fixed raters, subject measured \(k\) raters. choice reporting specific type ICC statistic based upon future intended usage rater. unclear whether rater rating average \(k\) raters taken final rating, meatrics reports ICC3 ICC3k. formula ICC(3, k) : \[ \frac{MS_{R}-MS_{E}}{MS_{R}} \] comparison, formula ICC(3, 1) : \[ \frac{MS_{R}-MS_{E}}{MS_{R} + (k-1)MS_{E}} \] can noted single-rater formula, adjusted fact common source variability amongst rater (\(MS_{E}\)).
code: # calculating icc across time of devices & expert graders icc_line(expert_graders, df2 = devices, variable = "msa_marbling")

title: Technical
text: Concordance Correlation Coefficient another measure inter-rater reliability. combines measures precision accuracy determine far data deviates perfect 45 degree line concordance. formula follows ranges -1 1, much like Pearson’s correlation coefficient: \[ \rho_c = \frac{2\rho\sigma_x\sigma_y}{\sigma_x^2+\sigma_y^2+(\mu_x-\mu_y)^2} \] \(x\) \(y\) represent two graders interest. bias correction factor formula adjusts bias measurements subtracting difference means two sets measurements denominator. ensures CCC appropriate measure Pearson’s systematic difference two graders. References: https://github.com/jmgirard/mReliability/wiki/Specific-agreement-coefficient https://statistics.laerd.com/spss-tutorials/fleiss-kappa--spss-statistics.php https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/301508/-cronbachs-alpha-reveal-reliability-information-----intracla https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4913118/

title: Histogram of Grader Differences — diff_histogram
text: function computes pairwise differences graders available data-frame outputs result histogram. summarises differences either taking mean, median maximum difference. allows partitions variable interest made differences can clearly observed along entire range variable.

title: Histogram of Grader Differences — diff_histogram
code: diff_histogram(   df,   device_status = FALSE,   variable,   partitions = 1,   grader_count = 3,   bins = 30,   diff_type = "mean" )

title: Histogram of Grader Differences — diff_histogram
text: df Input dataframe long format. device_status boolean denoting df device data-frame; default assumes grader data-frame. variable valid column name denoting variable interest. partitions integer specifying many groups split variable . grader_count integer specifying many graders data-frame. bins integer specifying bin-size. diff_type Either "mean", "median" "maximum", specifying kind difference take; default mean.

title: Histogram of Grader Differences — diff_histogram
text: ggplot2 histogram absolute differences.

title: Histogram of Grader Differences — diff_histogram
code: data("expert_graders", package = "meatrics") diff_histogram(expert_graders, variable = "msa_marbling", partitions = 4, grader_count = 3)
